articles.title: From Cape Town to London, Deo Kato runs to challenge racism and reclaim the migration narrative
articles.summary: Step by step, mile by mile, Deo Kato ran his way across a continent — and beyond. After a year and a half on the road, the Ugandan British runner and campaigner has become the first person to run from Cape Town to London.
articles.content:
The 8,262-mile journey took him through 21 countries, transforming an extraordinary physical feat into a powerful act of activism, aimed at confronting racism and reshaping how migration is understood.

Born in Uganda and raised in the United Kingdom, Deo first took up running to manage his health. Over time, that personal discipline grew into a journey of purpose, connecting endurance with identity, protest and hope.

Turning point

In 2020, a moment of global reckoning around racial injustice – the murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis – became a turning point for Deo. He realised his running could serve a purpose beyond endurance.

“I thought, ‘I have to do something about this. Whether it’s small or big, I want to use my running to create change and speak out against racial injustice,’” he explained.

That conviction led him to run ten kilometres every day for 381 days, marking each day of the Montgomery Bus Boycott, a pivotal moment in the United States civil rights movement.

He told himself, “I’m going to keep doing this for as long as I can because this is how change happens.”

© IOM/Joe Newman Day after day, Deo pushed forward, turning physical endurance into a form of activism aimed at confronting racism and amplifying conversations around migration and justice.

Retracing migration routes

From this commitment, Deo set out to run from Cape Town to London, symbolically retracing humanity’s earliest migration routes from Africa.

The road ahead was long and arduous. Scaling mountains, crossing deserts, and running through wildlife reserves, Deo moved through landscapes that constantly shifted around him.

“It feels incredible just to be moving. Then, suddenly, I see elephants and children start running beside me,” he shared.

Barriers and restrictions

Along the way, Deo witnessed how complex and restrictive migration can be, particularly for people displaced by climate impacts, economic pressure, or conflict.

He saw how limited regular pathways and movement restrictions leave many people effectively unable to move within their own regions, trapping them in unsafe or uncertain situations and cutting off routes to safety.

“Some people end up detained simply for trying to flee conflict or because they are seen as outsiders. Even when they have the correct paperwork, they can still be held.”

The further I travelled along the migration route, the more I was viewed as an irregular migrant.

Deo himself faced similar barriers. At one point, he was detained despite having the correct documents. In other areas, he was forced to reroute his journey because of conflict or restricted access.

As he travelled north towards Europe, the scrutiny intensified.

“The further I travelled along the migration route, the more I was viewed as an irregular migrant. People would call the police simply because they saw someone they thought didn’t belong passing through their area,” he explained.

© Courtesy of Deo Kato Crossing some of the world’s most spectacular and unforgiving terrain, Deo experienced Africa on foot, where nature and movement shaped every mile of his journey.

Community support

Despite the challenges, Deo’s journey was sustained by community support. Along the way, local runners, strangers, and online supporters joined him. Those moments of shared effort and solidarity kept him going.

“Without that community support, I would not have succeeded on this journey. It’s what truly gave it meaning,” he said.

His journey was never about endurance alone. It was about reclaiming the story of migration – a story rooted in resilience, human progress, and development.

“People move for so many reasons, and each journey tells a human story,” Deo emphasised.

Looking ahead, he plans to keep using his platform as a form of activism, continuing to speak about migration, belonging, and shared humanity. As he puts it, “Don’t limit yourself. Believe in your power to create change.”
articles.source: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

articles.personality_title: Deo Kato runs 8,262 miles from Cape Town to London to challenge racism and migration barriers
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Deo Kato, born in Uganda and raised in the UK, began running to improve his health. After the 2020 global protests against racial injustice, he decided to use running as a way to speak out against racism and reshape how people think about migration.

**What happened** – Over a year and a half, Deo ran 8,262 miles through 21 countries, making him the first person to run from Cape Town, South Africa, to London, England. Along the way, he faced tough landscapes like mountains and deserts, and also experienced difficulties such as being detained despite having proper papers.

**Impact** – Deo’s journey showed how hard it can be for many people to move freely, especially those escaping conflict or climate problems. His run turned into a form of protest that raised awareness about the challenges migrants face and the unfair treatment they often receive.

**What's next step** – Deo plans to continue using running and his story to talk about migration and belonging. He hopes to inspire others to believe in their ability to create change and to keep the conversation going about fairness and human rights.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Deo Kato’s long run from Africa to Europe used physical endurance to highlight migration struggles and fight racism along the way.
articles.personality_title_fr: Deo Kato court 13 300 km de Cape Town à Londres pour défier le racisme et les barrières migratoires
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Deo Kato, né en Ouganda et élevé au Royaume-Uni, a commencé à courir pour améliorer sa santé. Après les manifestations mondiales contre l’injustice raciale en 2020, il a décidé d’utiliser la course pour dénoncer le racisme et changer la manière dont on perçoit la migration.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Pendant un an et demi, Deo a couru 13 300 km à travers 21 pays, devenant la première personne à relier Cape Town, en Afrique du Sud, à Londres, en Angleterre, à pied. Il a affronté des paysages difficiles comme des montagnes et des déserts, et a aussi vécu des moments compliqués, comme être détenu malgré ses papiers en règle.

**Impact** – Le parcours de Deo a montré combien il est difficile pour beaucoup de personnes de se déplacer librement, surtout pour celles qui fuient les conflits ou les problèmes climatiques. Sa course est devenue une forme de protestation qui a mis en lumière les défis des migrants et les injustices qu’ils subissent.

**Prochaine étape** – Deo prévoit de continuer à utiliser la course et son histoire pour parler de migration et d’appartenance. Il souhaite inspirer les autres à croire en leur capacité à changer les choses et à poursuivre le débat sur l’égalité et les droits humains.

**Message clé en une phrase** – Le long parcours de Deo Kato d’Afrique à l’Europe a transformé son endurance physique en un moyen de montrer les difficultés des migrants et de lutter contre le racisme.
articles.personality_title_es: Deo Kato corre 13,300 km de Ciudad del Cabo a Londres para desafiar el racismo y las barreras migratorias

articles.title: Beyond the bylines: How Kant Kaw turned a dream into a 15-year fight for equality in Myanmar
articles.summary: “Women often carry heavier emotional burdens. Without mental resilience, it is easy to break so I protect myself carefully.”
articles.content:
Exile Hub is one of Global Voices’ partners in Southeast Asia, emerging in response to the 2021 coup in Myanmar, focusing on empowering journalists and human rights defenders. This edited article is republished under a content partnership agreement.

Kant Kaw’s journey into journalism officially began in 2009, but her story started long before that. As a child, she devoured books of every kind, captivated by the power of language. She dreamed of becoming a writer, yet understood early that writing alone could not sustain her. So she pursued practical jobs while holding on to her passion.

Everything changed the day she discovered journalism. For her, it was the perfect convergence of purpose and livelihood. It allowed her to write, to witness, and to serve the public. Fifteen years later, she remains in the field, saying that she never stopped loving the work.

“I absolutely love thinking up and writing news and article ideas. I can't give it up.”

Breaking the silence on oppression

Kant Kaw soon realized that her calling extended beyond reporting events as they unfolded. She felt compelled to disclose the struggles that women in Myanmar face every day.

“I met women who had to carry their fear in silence, yet still found the strength to protect their children and families. They wake up every morning choosing survival. In our conversations, I saw not weakness, but extraordinary strength — especially during moments of political upheaval.”

Through Kant Kaw’s work, stories that might otherwise have remained untold reached wider audiences. For example, she shone a light on the realities of a young mother in a conflict-affected township who begins each day calculating risk, choosing safer routes to buy food, wondering whether her child’s school will be open, and navigating military checkpoints.

She also documented moments of collective trauma: village raids where women were detained and interrogated as their children looked on; instances of sexual harassment and threats used to instill fear or extract information. After their release, many survivors remained silent, constrained by stigma and the constant fear of retaliation.

Fighting gender bias, one article at a time

Inside the newsroom, discrimination seemed unavoidable. Women were routinely underestimated, sidelined, or given fewer opportunities. In response, Kant Kaw pushed herself to excel in her field.

“When I faced discrimination, I used my work to prove that I should not be underestimated as a woman, and I succeeded.”

She grew bolder, fueled by the writings and achievements of women authors whose strength inspired her more deeply than any male success story could. She is committed to amplifying women’s stories and nurturing their talents, recognizing storytelling as an effective means to do so.

Care as a practice for sustaining the work

Years of reporting, especially in post-coup Myanmar, have taken a toll. These days, she practices intentional self-care to sustain her work: music, hiking, friendships, and proactive emotional problem-solving.

She gives care as much as she receives it, offering support and presence to friends who struggle. She knows the stakes:

“Women often carry heavier emotional burdens. Without mental resilience, it is easy to break, so I protect myself carefully.”

Her dream of becoming a writer did come true — just not in the way she first imagined. She writes for the public, for women whose voices have been muted by injustice, and continues to write as an act of resistance, a record of truth, and a source of hope.

Through her writing, she pushes back against silence, against injustice, and against anyone who dares to underestimate what a woman can do.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights Kant Kaw's 15-year commitment to journalism focused on exposing gender-based oppression and human rights abuses in Myanmar, amplifying marginalized women's voices during political upheaval. It demonstrates significant positive real-world impact by promoting equality and resilience in a conflict-affected society, with substantial context and personal narrative illustrating the struggle and progress.
articles.personality_title: Kant Kaw’s 15-year fight to share women’s stories in Myanmar
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Kant Kaw is a journalist from Myanmar who began her career in 2009. Myanmar has faced political struggles and a military coup in 2021, which made life harder for many people, especially women. Many women’s stories about fear, survival, and courage had not been told before.

**What happened** – Over 15 years, Kant Kaw has reported on the challenges women face in Myanmar. She shares stories of women living in conflict areas, dealing with military checkpoints, and facing harassment. Kant Kaw also fights gender bias in her newsroom, proving her skills through her work. She uses storytelling to bring attention to women’s voices that are often ignored.

**Impact** – Kant Kaw’s work helps people outside Myanmar understand the struggles of women living through conflict and oppression. By reporting these stories, she gives strength to those who feel silenced and challenges unfair treatment of women both in society and in her workplace. Her writing acts as a record of truth and resistance.

**What’s next step** – Kant Kaw continues to write and support other women journalists. She practices self-care to keep going despite the emotional challenges. Her work may inspire more women in Myanmar and beyond to speak out and share their experiences.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For 15 years, Kant Kaw has used journalism to reveal women’s hidden struggles in Myanmar and to fight for equality through the power of storytelling.
articles.personality_title_fr: Kant Kaw : 15 ans de combat pour raconter les histoires des femmes au Myanmar
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Kant Kaw est une journaliste du Myanmar qui a commencé sa carrière en 2009. Le Myanmar a connu des luttes politiques et un coup d’État militaire en 2021, rendant la vie difficile pour beaucoup, surtout pour les femmes. Beaucoup d’histoires de femmes sur la peur, la survie et le courage n’avaient pas été racontées.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Pendant 15 ans, Kant Kaw a raconté les défis que les femmes affrontent au Myanmar. Elle partage des histoires de femmes vivant dans des zones de conflit, affrontant des barrages militaires et du harcèlement. Kant Kaw combat aussi les préjugés sexistes dans son travail, prouvant ses compétences par ses articles. Elle utilise le récit pour donner voix à celles qui sont souvent ignorées.

**Impact** – Le travail de Kant Kaw aide les gens à l’extérieur du Myanmar à comprendre les luttes des femmes vivant dans l’oppression. En racontant ces histoires, elle donne de la force à celles qui se sentent réduites au silence et défie les traitements injustes envers les femmes, dans la société et au travail. Son écriture est un acte de vérité et de résistance.

**Prochaine étape** – Kant Kaw continue d’écrire et de soutenir d’autres femmes journalistes. Elle prend soin d’elle pour tenir face aux défis émotionnels. Son travail pourrait inspirer plus de femmes au Myanmar et ailleurs à s’exprimer et partager leurs expériences.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Depuis 15 ans, Kant Kaw utilise le journalisme pour révéler les luttes cachées des femmes au Myanmar et lutter pour l’égalité grâce au pouvoir des histoires.
articles.personality_title_es: Kant Kaw: 15 años luchando por contar las historias de mujeres en Myanmar
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Kant Kaw es una periodista de Myanmar que comenzó su carrera en 2009. Myanmar ha enfrentado problemas políticos y un golpe militar en 2021, lo que dificultó la vida de muchas personas, especialmente de las mujeres. Muchas historias sobre el miedo, la supervivencia y el valor de las mujeres no se habían contado.

**Qué pasó** – Durante 15 años, Kant Kaw ha informado sobre los desafíos que enfrentan las mujeres en Myanmar. Comparte historias de mujeres que viven en zonas de conflicto, que enfrentan puntos de control militares y acoso. Kant Kaw también lucha contra la discriminación de género en su trabajo, demostrando sus habilidades con sus reportajes. Usa la narración para dar voz a quienes suelen ser ignoradas.

**Impacto** – El trabajo de Kant Kaw ayuda a que personas fuera de Myanmar entiendan las dificultades de las mujeres que viven bajo opresión. Al contar estas historias, da fuerza a quienes se sienten silenciadas y desafía el trato injusto hacia las mujeres en la sociedad y en el trabajo. Su escritura es un acto de verdad y resistencia.

**Próximo paso** – Kant Kaw sigue escribiendo y apoyando a otras mujeres periodistas. Practica el cuidado personal para continuar pese a los retos emocionales. Su trabajo podría inspirar a más mujeres en Myanmar y en otros lugares a expresarse y compartir sus experiencias.

**Una frase clave** – Durante 15 años, Kant Kaw ha usado el periodismo para mostrar las luchas ocultas de las mujeres en Myanmar y luchar por la igualdad a través del poder de contar historias.

articles.title: How could the reopening of Gaza's Rafah crossing change the humanitarian situation?
articles.summary: Ambulances from the Egyptian side of the Rafah border crossing have been seen heading into Gaza. The reopening of the enclave's southern crossing marks a major step in the US-backed peace plans' second phase. But for the moment, the Rafah gate is only being used on a trial basis - and key details are still unclear. Many Palestinians have been waiting for this moment, as they head to Egypt for medical treatment. Analysis by Dr. James Smith, deputy director of UCL's humanitarian policy and practice program.
articles.content:
Ambulances from the Egyptian side of the Rafah border crossing have been seen heading into Gaza. The reopening of the enclave's southern crossing marks a major step in the US-backed peace plans' second phase. But for the moment, the Rafah gate is only being used on a trial basis - and key details are still unclear. Many Palestinians have been waiting for this moment, as they head to Egypt for medical treatment. Analysis by Dr. James Smith, deputy director of UCL's humanitarian policy and practice program.

Video by: Catherine VIETTE
articles.source: Health: news, videos, reports and analysis - France 24
articles.reasoning: The reopening of Gaza's Rafah crossing represents a significant humanitarian development, enabling Palestinians to access medical treatment and potentially improving the humanitarian situation in the region. This event has broad significance for many people affected by the conflict and is a meaningful step in peace efforts, though it is currently in a trial phase with some uncertainties.
articles.personality_title: Reopening of Gaza’s Rafah crossing offers new hope for medical aid
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Gaza has been cut off from many outside areas due to conflicts, making it hard for people to get medical help and supplies. The Rafah crossing, which connects Gaza to Egypt, has been closed for a long time.

**What happened** – Ambulances from Egypt have recently been seen entering Gaza through the Rafah crossing. This reopening is part of the second phase of peace plans supported by the United States. Right now, the crossing is open only on a trial basis, so not all details about how it will work are clear yet.

**Impact** – Many Palestinians have been waiting for this moment because they need to travel to Egypt for medical treatment that is not available in Gaza. Opening the crossing can help patients get urgent care, which could save lives and improve health conditions in the area.

**What’s next step** – Officials will monitor the trial phase of the crossing to see how it works and decide if it can stay open longer or be expanded. This could lead to more regular travel and aid flow between Gaza and Egypt.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The trial reopening of the Rafah crossing allows Palestinians in Gaza to access crucial medical treatment in Egypt for the first time in a long while, marking an important step in easing the region’s humanitarian challenges.
articles.personality_title_fr: La réouverture du passage de Rafah à Gaza apporte un nouvel espoir pour les soins médicaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Gaza est isolée depuis longtemps à cause des conflits, ce qui rend difficile l’accès aux soins médicaux et aux fournitures. Le passage de Rafah, qui relie Gaza à l’Égypte, était fermé depuis longtemps.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des ambulances égyptiennes ont récemment été vues entrant à Gaza par le passage de Rafah. Cette réouverture fait partie de la deuxième phase des plans de paix soutenus par les États-Unis. Pour l’instant, le passage est ouvert à titre d’essai, donc tous les détails ne sont pas encore clairs.

**Impact** – Beaucoup de Palestiniens attendaient ce moment car ils ont besoin de se rendre en Égypte pour des soins médicaux qui ne sont pas disponibles à Gaza. Ouvrir ce passage peut aider les patients à recevoir des soins urgents, ce qui pourrait sauver des vies et améliorer la santé dans la région.

**Prochaine étape** – Les responsables vont surveiller cette phase d’essai pour voir comment cela fonctionne et décider si le passage peut rester ouvert plus longtemps ou être étendu. Cela pourrait permettre des déplacements et une aide plus réguliers entre Gaza et l’Égypte.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La réouverture à l’essai du passage de Rafah permet aux Palestiniens de Gaza d’accéder pour la première fois depuis longtemps à des soins médicaux essentiels en Égypte, marquant une étape importante pour améliorer la situation humanitaire.
articles.personality_title_es: La reapertura del cruce de Rafah en Gaza ofrece nueva esperanza para la atención médica
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Gaza ha estado aislada durante mucho tiempo debido a conflictos, lo que dificulta el acceso a atención médica y suministros. El cruce de Rafah, que conecta Gaza con Egipto, ha estado cerrado por mucho tiempo.

**Qué pasó** – Ambulancias desde Egipto han sido vistas entrando a Gaza por el cruce de Rafah. Esta reapertura es parte de la segunda fase de los planes de paz apoyados por Estados Unidos. Por ahora, el cruce está abierto solo en una fase de prueba, por lo que no todos los detalles están claros.

**Impacto** – Muchos palestinos han esperado este momento porque necesitan viajar a Egipto para recibir tratamiento médico que no está disponible en Gaza. Abrir el cruce puede ayudar a que los pacientes reciban atención urgente, lo que podría salvar vidas y mejorar la salud en la región.

**Próximo paso** – Las autoridades observarán la fase de prueba para ver cómo funciona y decidir si el cruce puede permanecer abierto más tiempo o ampliarse. Esto podría permitir viajes y flujo de ayuda más regulares entre Gaza y Egipto.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La reapertura en fase de prueba del cruce de Rafah permite a los palestinos en Gaza acceder a tratamiento médico crucial en Egipto por primera vez en mucho tiempo, marcando un paso importante para aliviar los desafíos humanitarios de la región.
